### 20CC #####################################################################

/20CC/Childrens_Songs_V2.sid
COMMENT: These are all Dutch songs, except Jingle Bells. Maybe they are also
         known as an English or German version. Before each song there is an
         8-16 second long intermezzo. When they are done, the tunes are played
         again in the same order, but without the intermezzos.
  TITLE: Roodkapje (0:11)
 ARTIST: <?>
  TITLE: Hopsasa heisasa (0:27)
 ARTIST: <?>
  TITLE: Lang zal die leven (0:50)
 ARTIST: <?>
  TITLE: Twee emmertjes water halen (1:05)
 ARTIST: <?>
  TITLE: Jingle Bells (1:30)
 ARTIST: James Pierpont
  TITLE: Roodborstje (1:53)
 ARTIST: <?>

  TITLE: Scotland the Brave (0:04)

 ARTIST: Johannes Brahms
  TITLE: <?> (1:54)
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Commercial break end tune.

/20CC/Dutch_Breeze_Mix-E_Load.sid
COMMENT: This rip plays a random selection of drums, bass, fx and lead
         which are selected in the demo.  The randomness starts after
         the 0:16 mark.

COMMENT: According to the demo this was ripped from, this version of the tune
         only uses four raster lines.

 ARTIST: Glen A. Larson & Stu Phillips

 ARTIST: Pete Carpenter & Mike Post

/20CC/Vlindertjes.sid
COMMENT: In a demo by Edwin van Santen, which he released about two years after
         the tune was made popular in the Papillion's crack intro, he states
         that he in fact composed the music. This demo contained a new version
         of the tune (/20CC/Vlindertjes_v2.sid). He explains how he had made
         the music two years earlier on some composer like Soundmonitor or
         something similar. While at a copyparty, someone stole his music disk
         which had the tune on it. This was his only copy of the tune. About
         two months later, the tune appeared on a Papillions' intro and no
         credit was given to van Santen.

/20CC/Words.sid
COMMENT: Inspired by Jeroen Tel's "Cybernoid II".

### AUDIAL ARTS/ #############################################################

### Rodney Balai #############################################################

/Audial_Arts/Balai_Rodney/Ooops_Up.sid
  TITLE: Ooops Up
 ARTIST: Snap
COMMENT: This tune was supposed to be part of the Soundtrack of the C64 version
         of "Ooops Up" by Demonware, but the project was cancelled.

/Audial_Arts/Balai_Rodney/Riemix.sid
COMMENT: The tune was originally made by Reyn Ouwehand on his synth.

/Audial_Arts/Balai_Rodney/Spijkerhoek.sid
  TITLE: Theme Spijkerhoek [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: The Hans van Eijck Project
COMMENT: Edwin van Santen's (20CC) version is covered here.

/Audial_Arts/Balai_Rodney/Wake_Me_Up_Before_You_Gogo.sid
  TITLE: Wake Me Up Before You Go Go
 ARTIST: Wham!

### Ronny Pasch ##############################################################

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Bla_Bla_Huh.sid
  TITLE: Busy Nosa
 ARTIST: Thomas Mogensen (DRAX)
COMMENT: Although this SID sounds remarkably similar to DRAX's original, it is
         in fact written by Ronny in a different player.

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Dwarf-Fly.sid
  TITLE: Dwarf Fly
 ARTIST: Klaus Grøngaard (Link)

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Humanoid.sid
  TITLE: Stakker Humanoid
 ARTIST: Humanoid
COMMENT: See /DEMOS/Digital_Acid_PSID.sid.

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Lame_and_Bad_A.sid
  TITLE: Lambada
 ARTIST: Kaoma

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Rain-Fan.sid
  TITLE: Rain Man - End Credits [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Hans Zimmer

/Audial_Arts/Pasch_Ronny/Venlo_Birthday.sid
  TITLE: Malbrouk s'en va-t-en guerre (0:00-0:41)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: An Arab tune that was brought to Europe during the crusades and
         became popular during the French revolution, ever sinced spawned
         many songs, including "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow".

### Patrick Peters ###########################################################

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Dirty_Cash.sid
  TITLE: Dirty Cash
 ARTIST: Adventures of Stevie V

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Holiday.sid
  TITLE: Holiday [from Madonna]
 ARTIST: Madonna

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Illusion.sid
  TITLE: Future Composer 3, Tune #3
 ARTIST: Patrick Peters (Softmaster)

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Lambada.sid
  TITLE: Lambada
 ARTIST: Kaoma
COMMENT: "I can tell you that the Lambada tune, used in our demo's/openings are
         from me. At that time I hadn't any player and I didn't want to spend
         too much time in making one. I ripped the 20CC player by analyzing the
         code in assembler. Then I programmed the codeblocks myself to get the
         Lambada tune right. I laughed when 20CC found out that their player
         was used and Falco Paul or Edwin van Santen hadn't made that tune
         earlier!!! They accused me of ripping routines etc. etc. Well.. they
         were right, I never claimed that it was my player but I merged my
         Lambada tune blocks via assembler into their old music blocks (I
         overwrote it). The funniest thing was that the Lambada tune from me
         was very populair at that time. When 20CC heard it they made their own
         Lambada tune, hehehehe..." (Patrick Peters)

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Reign_of_Pain_part_5.sid
  TITLE: Savage, Tune #4 (0:00-0:07)
 ARTIST: Jeroen Tel

/Audial_Arts/Peters_Patrick/Tendance_part_5.sid
  TITLE: Lessons In Love
 ARTIST: Level 42

### WALLY BEBEN ##############################################################

/Beben_Wally/Ball_Game.sid
COMMENT: Also used in the game "Hellhole", (c) 1990 CRL Group.

/Beben_Wally/Dark_Side.sid
COMMENT: Also used in the game "Driller II" without Beben's permission.

/Beben_Wally/Hammerfist.sid
COMMENT: Also used in the game "First Samurai".

/Beben_Wally/Merry_Xmas.sid
  TITLE: Mary's Boy Child
 ARTIST: Harry Belafonte

/Beben_Wally/Starslayer.sid
COMMENT: Also used later in the game "Return of the Space Warriors", (c) 1988
         Power Group.

/Beben_Wally/Summer_Olympiad.sid
COMMENT: Despite the game crediting the music to both Wally Beben & Ian
         Crabtree, none of Ian's music is in the game. Although Ian did write
         music for this game, it was pulled "at the 11th hour." (Info from Ian
         Crabtree.)

COMMENT: Originally, the Depeche_Mode_Songs.sid set of SIDs was to be used in
         this game, but at the last minute the programmer was afraid of
         copyright issues and asked JB to create some original tunes.

### JENS BLIDON ##############################################################

/Blidon_Jens/Birthday.sid
COMMENT: Also used as the intro tune for Magic Disk 64 between 08/89 and 05/91.

/Blidon_Jens/Counter_Force.sid
COMMENT: All tunes are almost like those in /Blidon_Jens/Metal_Force.sid.
(#6)
  TITLE: Don't Make Me Wait [from Into The Dragon]
 ARTIST: Bomb the Bass

/Blidon_Jens/Crocketts_Theme.sid
  TITLE: Crockett's Theme [from the TV series Miami Vice]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

/Blidon_Jens/First_Time.sid
COMMENT: Same as /Blidon_Jens/Magic_Writer.sid #4.

/Blidon_Jens/Its_A_Sin.sid
  TITLE: It's a Sin [from Actually]
 ARTIST: Pet Shop Boys

/Blidon_Jens/Magic_Disk_64_Issue_08_89.sid
COMMENT: Also used in Magic Disk 64 Issue 09/89.

/Blidon_Jens/Magic_Writer.sid
COMMENT: All these tunes had an adjustable speed variable, which was set to the
         default value in this rip.

/Blidon_Jens/Metal_Force.sid
COMMENT: All tunes are almost like those in /Blidon_Jens/Counter_Force.sid.
(#6)
  TITLE: Don't Make Me Wait [from Into The Dragon]
 ARTIST: Bomb the Bass

### ED BOGAS #################################################################

/Bogas_Ed/4th_and_Inches.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: The Star Spangled Banner (National Anthem of the U.S.A.)
 ARTIST: Sir Francis Scott Key (lyrics), John Stafford Smith (music)
COMMENT: The melody of the US national anthem ironically comes from a popular
         English drinking song, "To Anacreon in Heaven."
(#2)
COMMENT: The "charge!" jingle.

### BOGG #####################################################################

/BOGG/
COMMENT: "BOGG is a variation on my surname MARSH, which in the dictionary
         means Flooded Land, Bog, Swamp and such like. I just added another G
         to make Bogg! I think my brother might have been called Boggy at
         school too." (BOGG)

/BOGG/Axel_F.sid
  TITLE: Axel F [from the movie Beverly Hills Cop]
 ARTIST: Harold Faltermeyer

### GEORG BRANDT #############################################################

/Brandt_Georg/Dein_ist_mein_ganzes_Herz.sid
  TITLE: Dein ist mein ganzes Herz [from Dein ist mein ganzes Herz]
 ARTIST: Heinz Rudolf Kunze

/Brandt_Georg/Magic_Bytes.sid
COMMENT: Used as the intro theme to many Magic Bytes games.

/Brandt_Georg/Mental_Warriors.sid
COMMENT: With this song the author had taken part in the same music competition
         of the German paper magazine 64'er that Chris Hülsbeck won with his
         "Shades".

/Brandt_Georg/Mini_Golf_PSID.sid
  TITLE: Night Talk [from the TV series Miami Vice]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

/Brandt_Georg/Mission_Overflow.sid
COMMENT: With this song the author had taken part in the same music competition
         of the German paper magazine 64'er that Chris Hülsbeck won with his
         "Shades".

/Brandt_Georg/Paranoia_Complex_PSID.sid
COMMENT: This tune was ripped from the 1987 'pre-release', which was actually a
         theft-copy spread by FAC. Perhaps because it was really 'published' by
         a cracker, Magic Bytes decided to let the game 'sit' for a while, then
         releasing it under a different name in 1990 (whose new name was Cyber
         World).

/Brandt_Georg/Tom_and_Jerry_PSID.sid
(#3)
  TITLE: Ouverture [from The Barber of Seville]
 ARTIST: Gioacchino Antonio Rossini
(#20)
  TITLE: Mexican Hat Dance
 ARTIST: Traditional

### NEIL BRENNAN #############################################################

/Brennan_Neil/
COMMENT: The HVSC team via their sources have checked all the original credits
         and found that most of the tunes that were supposedly done by Greg
         Holland were in fact made by Neil Brennan. For most of the games Greg
         Holland was the graphic artist rather than the composer. The HVSC Crew
         also has confirmation of this fact from a senior employee of Beam
         Software, who was on Melbourne House's main programming team at the
         time.

/Brennan_Neil/Doc_the_Destroyer.sid
  TITLE: Judge Dredd, Tune #1 (0:38-0:52)
 ARTIST: Neil Brennan
COMMENT: Covers from 0:46-0:56 in Judge Dredd.

/Brennan_Neil/Hobbit.sid
(#2)
  TITLE: March of Triumph [from Aida]
 ARTIST: Giuseppe Verdi
(#5)
COMMENT: This tune was later used in the game "Fist II: The Legend Continues".

/Brennan_Neil/Starion.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Ride of the Valkyries
 ARTIST: Richard Wagner
(#2)
  TITLE: Ride of the Valkyries
 ARTIST: Richard Wagner

### ALLISTER BRIMBLE #########################################################

/Brimble_Allister/
COMMENT: Comments by Allister Brimble are denoted (AB).

/Brimble_Allister/Murray_Mouse.sid
COMMENT: Converted from the Spectrum version.

/Brimble_Allister/Prince_Clumsy.sid
COMMENT: Also used in the game 'The Sword and The Rose', (c) 1991 Codemasters.

/Brimble_Allister/Wild_West_Seymour.sid
COMMENT: "Yes at that time I was trying to copy all the great C64 musicians.
         The drum sound was taken from Rob Hubbards music and the other
         instruments were delibarately similar to David Whittakers stuff which
         I really liked." (AB)
(#2)
  TITLE: Dragnet Theme
 ARTIST: Miklós Rózsa & Walter Schumann

### MARK CLEMENTS ############################################################

/Clements_Mark/Heatseeker_version_1.sid
COMMENT: This was meant to be the music used in Thalamus' 'Heatseeker', however
         the programmer Paul O'Malley didn't give Mark enough memory to play
         with and so the music was unused. Mark states that this music suits
         the game better.

/Clements_Mark/Heatseeker_version_2.sid
COMMENT: A second attempt of the music for Thalamus' 'Heatseeker', however the
         programmer Paul O'Malley didn't give Mark enough memory to play with
         and so the music was unused.

/Clements_Mark/Quedex.sid
  TITLE: Quedex, Tune #2
 ARTIST: Matt Gray

  TITLE: Walking in a Winter Wonderland
 ARTIST: The Andrews Sisters

         /Crabtree_Ian/Moun.sid.

/Crowther_Antony/R1D1.sid

         the tune, but I think it was one that Tony had got an idea for, and I
         showed him how to turn it into a fully fledged piece.....I think that
         was the one - one day I'll have a listen....:)" (Comment is by Ben
         Daglish)

/Crowther_Antony/Zig_Zag.sid
COMMENT: Together with Michael Winterberg, Antony Crowther pioneered the art of
         multiple-X players. Zigzag, released in 1987, is one of the very first
         examples of a 4X routine, updating sound parameters 200 times a
         second.
(#1)
  TITLE: Go For Gold
 ARTIST: Antony Crowther

### BEN DAGLISH ##############################################################

/Daglish_Ben/
COMMENT: Comments from Ben Daglish are denoted (BD)
         Q: Is it Ben or Benn?
         A: "Ben is my real name....Benn was a nick from Compuserve days - the
         double letter was all the rage...Ratt, Bogg etc. etc." (BD)

         Sound In Computers.

COMMENT: Other version of Ark Pandora, Tune #3.
(#11)
   NAME: Rainbow-Dragon
COMMENT: A slightly remixed version of a tune "which I'd written a little while
         before, I think, for a game demo that was sent to whatever Gremlin was
         called before it was Gremlin - they had a little SW house over the
         'Just Micro' shop..." (BD) It was possibly meant to be a tune for the
         game Rainbow Dragon, later released by Firebird, and it was never
         used.

(#1)
COMMENT: A high proportion of copies of the game have a bug in this
         tune where it falls out of synch at the 1:18 mark.  This was
         due to some code overwriting some of the music player data.
         This rip is however a clean bug-free version.

/Daglish_Ben/Last_Ninja.sid
COMMENT: "I got the phone call from Mark [Cale] asking me to write some level
         tunes - I wrote the music, went down there [to System 3] to meet
         Archer Maclean (? I think it was Arch that put the driver in.....),
         got offered Mark Cale's slightly-dodgy-import-status left-hand-drive
         BMW, said "no thanks, I'll have the cash please" and that was that."
         (BD)
         Q: How was Anthony Lees to work with?
         A: "Only met the guy once - on that one day - he said 'hi' - I said
         'hi' - that was about it." (BD)
         The titles of the individual tunes found below are based on as they
         appear in the game.
(#1)
   NAME: The Wilderness (loader)
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
(#2)
   NAME: Palace Gardens (loader)
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
COMMENT: "I did six tunes for LN, the first of which was the one involving the
         creepy jungle music (....which was and still is my favourite) - the
         inspiration is hard to nail down, but it was probably the film
         'Apocalypse Now' - very dense, troubled and scary moods were evoked."
         (Comment from Anthony Lees)
(#3)
   NAME: The Wastelands (loader)
 AUTHOR: Ben Daglish
(#4)
   NAME: The Palace (loader)
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
(#5)
   NAME: The Inner Sanctum (loader)
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
COMMENT: Interesting comment in this binary: "DONE BY ANTHONY LEES FOR SYSTEM 3
         ON 5/4/87...EAT YER HEART OUT GALWAY!".
(#6)
   NAME: The Wastelands
 AUTHOR: Ben Daglish
(#7)
   NAME: The Wilderness
 AUTHOR: Ben Daglish
(#8)
   NAME: Palace Gardens
 AUTHOR: Ben Daglish
(#9)
   NAME: The Dungeons
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
(#10)
   NAME: The Palace
 AUTHOR: Anthony Lees
(#11)
   NAME: The Dungeons (loader)
 AUTHOR: Ben Daglish
COMMENT: This is also the tune for "The Inner Sanctum".

COMMENT: "I made this song on the Amiga at first, for the Fairlight demo 'My
         Room'. I listened to The Dungeon Master/Triad's cover on the C64 and
         it was so damn lousy, I had to make my own C64 version of it." (TD)

/Danko_Tomas/Sanxion_Tapeloader.sid
  TITLE: Thalamusik [from Sanxion]
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/Danko_Tomas/Shock_Magazine.sid
  TITLE: Rubicon, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Jeroen Tel
COMMENT: "They wanted a title-theme for Shock Magazine, and gave me the first
         issue. There was a song in there, and I had no clue what it really
         was but thought it captured the feel of the entire magazine. So I
         simply made a cover of it, Danko style. I never had any hangups about
         having to do it all, music is all about sharing and developing ideas
         together in order to reach higher grounds. The chords aren't
         identical to Jeroen's version, in fact we had a little thing over
         that at a party in Oslo back in '94 or so. We hung over a keyboard
         and I played the chords my style, and he went like 'No! It's like
         THIS!' and I said 'Well, I want it THIS way!'. *grin* One of the guys
         at the party leaned over to me and whispered that he in fact
         preferred my version of the track. *smirk* Jeroen superimposed a sus2
         chord throughout the progression until it folds back to the tonic,
         where the sus2 becomes a m7. It's a nice move, one that I personally
         use quite a lot myself. But this time around I expanded the
         progression to plain chords following the bassline.
         After I had done the tune I found out that it was from Rubicon, but
         to me it doesn't matter.
         Later on I made a remix of it, called it Schizomix, with weird
         sounds. Because Rubicon had been a double-speed song, or something
         similar, I wanted to make weird and similar sounds but in a single-
         speed player. And that's all it was, a messed up version of my first
         cover so to speak." (TD)

/Danko_Tomas/Shock_Magazine_Schizomix.sid
  TITLE: Rubicon, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Jeroen Tel
COMMENT: See comment for /Danko_Tomas/Shock_Magazine.sid.

/Danko_Tomas/Smooth_Criminal.sid
  TITLE: Smooth Criminal [from Bad]
 ARTIST: Michael Jackson

/Danko_Tomas/Spectre_of_Ice.sid
  TITLE: <?> [from the Amiga MOD module]
 ARTIST: Tomas Danko

/Danko_Tomas/Suffix_Unknown.sid
COMMENT: Similar to /Danko_Tomas/Complications.sid. Perhaps a tangential
         version.

/Danko_Tomas/Tre_Pepparkaksgubbar.sid
  TITLE: Tre pepparkaksgubbar
 ARTIST: Alice Tegnér
COMMENT: Swedish Christmas-tune.

/Danko_Tomas/White_Christmas.sid
  TITLE: White Christmas
 ARTIST: Irving Berlin

### RICHARD "DEEK" RINN ######################################################

/Deek/
COMMENT: Richard Rinn's own comments are indicated by (RR).

/Deek/Crimson.sid
COMMENT: "This one is for TDM. Quite a few musical type people (JCH etc.) that
         I send to every decade or so have liked this one (or what there is of
         it so far!). Personally I'm finding that it's a bit on the boring
         side, sooooo i'm going to start it from scratch on newplayer 15 so I
         have better control over the vibrato and stuff. It's gonna be quite a
         long 'un." (RR)

/Deek/Dead_Tunes.sid
COMMENT: "This is the GAME OVER jingle for the game Doug is working on." (RR)

/Deek/Extreme.sid
COMMENT: This is possibly the original set of tunes of sound effects that were
         to be used in Digital Integration's game 'Extreme' but other music by
         Sonic Graffiti was used in the finished game.

 ARTIST: David Whittaker
COMMENT: Covers the Spectrum version of the tune.

COMMENT: "This also needs a LOOOOOTTTTAAA work! The sounds are pretty awful
         (just have a listen to that bass-drum), but i'll fix 'em next time I
         do some work on the tune. The bassline isn't bad, but that crap bass
         patch doesn't do it much justice... I think this'll be good when I
         finish it (IF! IIIFF!!)" (RR)

  TITLE: Funkish

         needed a bit of music urgently for his demo (I should have known he
         was lying!). The demo is on this disk titled summat like ROTATIONAL. I
         think the music is quite nice." (RR)

         them!), this is just a start for a tune. When the right tune comes
         along (or when I decide to make a tune to go with it), i'll use this."
         (RR)

         when I done it but heard it too many times, and now it grates!
         AARRGHHH!!!!" (RR)

/DEMOS/In_Your_Dreams.sid
COMMENT: "My first SID ever. Participated in proxy 1886 Party oldskool music
         competition and came 6th there. I expected people to vote it higher,
         because it was the only song made with c64 in the whole competition.
         This song was done on 8580 and I didn't realise to turn off the
         filters on channel 1, so if you're listening this with 6581rev1 then
         don't panic if the channel 1 sounds strange" (Jussi Hannula)

/DEMOS/Synth_Sample.sid
COMMENT: All comments for this file are by Georg Feil himself and are denoted
         by (GF).
         "I wrote it around '84 or '85 as a demo for my music editor called
         'Synth'. I was going to University of Waterloo at the time and just
         gave it to a friend of mine... didn't even bother to put my name on
         the thing. Anyway it soon started cropping up all over the place.
         I never made any sequels with music, although there was something with
         annoying sound effects done in the same style as Synth Sample that I
         posted in the beginning of 1994. So any music you see that looks like
         a sequel or has graphics added was done by someone else.
         Anyway the computer bust of 85/86(?) hit and Synth was never marketed.
         I had been negotiating with a software company but they went out of
         business. By that time I was working on a new version of Synth that
         was a sequencer program for Midi instruments (called MSS), and had
         joined my first band. I've been in a couple other bands since then,
         the last one was called SugarPush and we came close to getting signed
         (but then broke up [...]). So I guess you can credit that little
         program with launching my musical career..." (GF)
(#1)
  TITLE: Stationary Ark
 ARTIST: John Mills-Cockell <?>
COMMENT: "Theme from Stationary Ark, a nature show on PBS. [...] It appears on
         Synth Sample as interpreted by a friend of mine. I didn't know what it
         was myself until I happened to see Stationary Ark one time. This song
         does not play properly on some C-64's where the SID chip filter is
         calibrated differently." (GF)
(#2)
  TITLE: Saturdays in Silezia
 ARTIST: Rational Youth
COMMENT: "A fluffy pop song I taped off the radio. Seemed simple enough to
         render on the C-64." (GF)
         Also used in the game Shocker.
(#3)
  TITLE: Spiral [from Spiral]
 ARTIST: Vangelis
(#4)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
COMMENT: A little free-hand adaptation.
         "I just thought this was ultra cool. Used as the music to The
         Exorcist, unfortunately." (GF)
(#5)
  TITLE: Magic Shadows, closing theme
 ARTIST: Harry Forbes
COMMENT: "Magic Shadows was a half-hour movie show on TV Ontario, sort of the
         Canadian equivalent of PBS. They'd show old movies in half-hour
         installments. I have no idea if there's an album. I taped it off the
         TV." (GF)
(#6)
  TITLE: Funeral Music for Queen Mary
 ARTIST: Henry Purcell
(#7)
  TITLE: Oxygene 2 [from Oxygene]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre
(#8)
  TITLE: Canon in D major
 ARTIST: Johann Pachelbel
COMMENT: "This is a very popular classical hit. I transcribed the notes from a
         Transactor or Compute! article (this is the only Synth Sample piece
         not transcribed by ear)." (GF)
(#9)
  TITLE: Enola Gay [from Organisation]
 ARTIST: Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (OMD)

/DEMOS/T_H_E_Y_Music_A.sid
  TITLE: The Chicken Song
 ARTIST: Philip Pope
COMMENT: Makes fun of all the SID Chicken Song covers made in the 80's. See
         /Hubbard_Rob/Chicken_Song.sid for more info...

/Detert_Thomas/Power.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Super Freak [from Street Songs]
 ARTIST: Rick James
COMMENT: MC Hammer covered this same tune as "U Can't Touch This!" (or maybe
         it's influenced by it).
         While the the Amiga versions of Demonware's games The Power and Ooops
         Up had digitracks of the Snap songs, Detert was instructed NOT to do a
         cover of The Power by Snap for this soundtrack, obviously the guys at
         Snap meanwhile changed their minds about their agreement with
         Demonware.
         The C64 version of Ooops Up was never finished, early soundtrack
         versions done by Rodney Balai did feature a cover of the Snap song
         though. (see /Audial_Arts/Balai_Rodney/Ooops_Up.sid)

/Detert_Thomas/PP_Hammer.sid
(#10)
  TITLE: Garden Party
 ARTIST: Mezzoforte

COMMENT: Same as /DEMOS/UNKNOWN/Ikari_Intro_Tune.sid but in a different key. In
         both versions the lead voice falls out of sync when it loops.

/DRAX/England.sid
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.

         would emulate the bird noises, so I helped him out." (By JCH)

/DRAX/Hermetic.sid
COMMENT: "This is the music for the game which was originally titled "Perplex".
         In the beginning DRAX did the soundtrack for the game while I made
         the sfx. At some time during the production of the music, DRAX thought
         he could use some help and I agreed to do some of the music. While the
         music and sfx was done in 1990, the game was put on ice by the
         Austrian guys as they became tired of it. Some years later they
         revived the project, finished it, and sold it to a German software
         house under the new name, "Hermetic"". (JCH)

 AUTHOR: Thomas Mogensen (DRAX)

### DRAX/Worktunes ###########################################################

/DRAX/Worktunes/
COMMENT: DRAX has given us permission to release his worktunes in HVSC. Any
         tunes that he has given a name, we have named to fall in line with
         HVSC standards. Any tune which he named 'Worktune' we have preserved
         the original file name, which was DRAX hammering the C64 keyboard at
         random to choose a name.

/DRAX/Worktunes/American_National_Anthem.sid
  TITLE: The Star Spangled Banner (National Anthem of the U.S.A.)
 ARTIST: Sir Francis Scott Key (lyrics), John Stafford Smith (music)

/DRAX/Worktunes/Bach-like.sid
  TITLE: Inventionen 1
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach

/DRAX/Worktunes/Bach.sid
  TITLE: Inventionen 1
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach

/DRAX/Worktunes/Blue_Monday_New_Order.sid
  TITLE: Blue Monday
 ARTIST: New Order

/DRAX/Worktunes/Conversion_of_Beethoven.sid
  TITLE: An die Freude [from Symphony No. 9 Op. 125 "Choral Symphony"]
 ARTIST: Ludwig van Beethoven

/DRAX/Worktunes/Dave_Stewart.sid
  TITLE: Lily Was Here [from the movie De Kassiere]
 ARTIST: David A. Stewart

/DRAX/Worktunes/Dejlig_er_den.sid
  TITLE: Dejlig er den himmelblå
 ARTIST: Traditional Danish folksong

/DRAX/Worktunes/Der_er_et_yndigt_land.sid
  TITLE: Der er et yndigt land
 ARTIST: Hans Ernst Krøyer (music), Adam G. Oehlenschlager (lyrics)
COMMENT: One of the Danish national anthems. The title translates as "There is
         a lovely land"

/DRAX/Worktunes/Det_var_en_Remix_in_MINOR.sid
  TITLE: Det var en lørdag aften
 ARTIST: Traditional Danish folksong

/DRAX/Worktunes/Eliminator_Hiscore.sid
  TITLE: Eliminator, Tune #2
 ARTIST: Jeroen Tel
COMMENT: Just like Tel's tune, it borrows parts from Gyroscope by Mark
         Alphingwood.

/DRAX/Worktunes/Eliminator_Title.sid
  TITLE: Eliminator, Tune #3
 ARTIST: Jeroen Tel

/DRAX/Worktunes/Flashdance_conversion.sid
  TITLE: What a Feeling [from Flashdance]
 ARTIST: Irene Cara

/DRAX/Worktunes/French_Fries.sid
  TITLE: French Fries
 ARTIST: Johannes Bjerregaard

/DRAX/Worktunes/Fuer_Elise.sid

### DRAX\ ####################################################################

### DAVID DUNN ###############################################################

/Dunn_David/Chiller.sid
COMMENT: This music is from Mastertronic's original release of Chiller.
         However, the ingame music (tune #2) was too close to Michael Jackson's
         'Thriller' for comfort, and so Mastertronic would not be sued, they
         withdrew the game and re-released it with a different non-offending
         tune #2. This is in /Dunn_David/Chiller_v2.sid. (Comment by Warren
         Pilkington and Jason Mackenzie (Kenz))

/Dunn_David/Chiller_v2.sid
COMMENT: See comment for /Dunn_David/Chiller.sid.

/Dunn_David/Elite.sid
COMMENT: Composed by Aidan Bell, C64 music and routine programmed by David Dunn
         with Ian Bell modifying some of the code.
(#2)
  TITLE: An der schönen blauen Donau (Blue Danube)
 ARTIST: Johann Strauß

(#3)
  TITLE: Wiegenlied (Lullaby)
 ARTIST: Johannes Brahms

/Dunn_David/High_Noon.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: High Noon (Do Not Forsake Me Oh My Darling) [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Dimitri Tiomkin (music), Ned Washington (lyrics)
(#2)
  TITLE: High Noon (Do Not Forsake Me Oh My Darling) [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Dimitri Tiomkin (music), Ned Washington (lyrics)
(#3)
  TITLE: High Noon (Do Not Forsake Me Oh My Darling) [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Dimitri Tiomkin (music), Ned Washington (lyrics)
(#5)
  TITLE: High Noon (Do Not Forsake Me Oh My Darling) [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Dimitri Tiomkin (music), Ned Washington (lyrics)

         permission to do so...

(#5)

COMMENT: "The Challenge" was the name of the musical score given away on a free
         audio cassette with original release copies of the game.
(#7)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.

         title is obviously a reference to this.

 ARTIST: Richard M. Sherman & Robert B. Sherman
  TITLE: Chim Chim Cher-ee [from the movie Mary Poppins] (4:23-4:59)
 ARTIST: Richard M. Sherman & Robert B. Sherman

  TITLE: Wizball, Tune #7
 ARTIST: Martin Galway

/Feekzoid/Word_PSID.sid
  TITLE: Olympic [from Ex:El]
 ARTIST: 808 State
COMMENT: 808 State wrote a special version of "Olympic" to be used as the title
         theme for the UK TV show "The Word" and this is what the SID covers.

/Feekzoid/Xanadu_PSID.sid
COMMENT: Similar melody to /Feekzoid/Nice_Feekzak_PSID.sid.

/Feekzoid/Xmas_Chortles_x-rated_PSID.sid
  TITLE: Another One Bites the Dust [from The Game] (2:06-2:18)
 ARTIST: Queen
COMMENT: This is just the first part of Queen's music.
         This one voice digi tune is a companion to the bizarre movie "Xmas
         Chortles" featuring Jason Mackenzie (Kenz) and friends in really manic
         scenes and behaviour, including setting fire to a Spectrum, re-making
         a Pepsi ad, lots of playing C64 Games and strange footage. The voice
         of Kenz is heard in the "Xmas Chortles" and "Merry Christmas" samples.
         According to Feekzoid, this tune was never supposed to be released.

### GÖSTA FEIWEIER ###########################################################

/Feiweier_Goesta/Conquest_unreleased.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Greensleeves
 ARTIST: Unknown
(#2)
  TITLE: Firelord, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Ben Daglish

/Feiweier_Goesta/Digital_Excess_Intro.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Batman (long)
 ARTIST: Jens-Christian Huus (JCH)
COMMENT: Not really a cover, but at least heavily inspired. The JCH tune was
         given to Feiweier as an example for a sound for a fading effect when
         he was to do the tune for this Digital Excess intro, he obviously got
         close =). (Info from Seven)

 ARTIST: Thomas Detert

 ARTIST: Laser Dance

         exchanged for a Romuzak version with a few different songs.

         Heusenstamm level
(#3)

         Francisco level

COMMENT: The Roll Over soundtrack by Feiweier wasn't used in the game, instead
         a soundtrack done by The Syndom and Gaston was used. (see
         /VARIOUS/S-Z/The_Syndrom/Roll_Over.sid)
         The tunes for the San Francisco and Heusenstamm levels were later used
         in Puxxle though. (see /Feiweier_Goesta/Puxxle.sid)
         (Info from Seven)

### MARTIN GALWAY ############################################################

/Galway_Martin/
COMMENT: Martin Galway's own comments are denoted by (MG).
         "I will never do rearrangements of those tunes on other instruments,
         the SID is what they're meant to be heard on. It would not be
         'updating' them to put them onto a different instrument. If you ever
         hear music from me on today's instruments, the tunes will be all-new
         (and probably a lot better)." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Arkanoid.sid
COMMENT: All except tune #1 cover the arcade version.
         This is the very first published tune on the C64 that used samples.
         "I'm glad you spotted 'Cobra' on the Spectrum, whose tune I was in
         love with and HAD to use somewhere else...! I figured no-one would
         complain if I used it a year later on the C64." (MG) (It got used in
         Arkanoid.)
         "Q: How did you get involved with using sampled sounds?
         MG: I figured out how samples were played by hacking into someone
         else's code... OK, I admit it... It was a drum synthesizer package
         called Digidrums, actually, so you could still say I was the first to
         include samples in a piece of music. [...] Never would I claim to have
         invented that technique, I just got it published first. In fact, I
         couldn't really figure out where they got the sample data, just that
         they were wiggling the volume register, so I tried to make up my own
         drum sample sounds in realtime - which is the flatulence stuff that
         shipped in 'Arkanoid'. [...] After the project was in the shops I
         gained access to some real drum samples, and I slid those into my own
         custom version of the tune. The one that's in the shops is kind of a
         collage of farts & burps, don't you think? [...] Later I was able to
         acquire some proper drum samples and by 'Game Over' it got quite
         sophisticated." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Arkanoid_PSID.sid
COMMENT: All except tune #1 cover the arcade version.
         This is the very first published tune on the C64 that used samples.
         "I'm glad you spotted 'Cobra' on the Spectrum, whose tune I was in
         love with and HAD to use somewhere else...! I figured no-one would
         complain if I used it a year later on the C64." (MG) (It got used in
         Arkanoid.)
         "Q: How did you get involved with using sampled sounds?
         MG: I figured out how samples were played by hacking into someone
         else's code... OK, I admit it... It was a drum synthesizer package
         called Digidrums, actually, so you could still say I was the first to
         include samples in a piece of music. [...] Never would I claim to have
         invented that technique, I just got it published first. In fact, I
         couldn't really figure out where they got the sample data, just that
         they were wiggling the volume register, so I tried to make up my own
         drum sample sounds in realtime - which is the flatulence stuff that
         shipped in 'Arkanoid'. [...] After the project was in the shops I
         gained access to some real drum samples, and I slid those into my own
         custom version of the tune. The one that's in the shops is kind of a
         collage of farts & burps, don't you think? [...] Later I was able to
         acquire some proper drum samples and by 'Game Over' it got quite
         sophisticated." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Athena.sid
COMMENT: The one that drove Galway insane was "'Athena', because after some
         years of increasing sound quality in the music, I finally had to come
         down... I only had 4K in which to fit the code and music." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Combat_School.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: I Wanna Be Your Drill Instructor [from the movie Full Metal Jacket]
 ARTIST: Abigail Mead

/Galway_Martin/Combat_School_PSID.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: I Wanna Be Your Drill Instructor [from the movie Full Metal Jacket]
 ARTIST: Abigail Mead

/Galway_Martin/Comic_Bakery.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: Tune #1 was also in the game "Top Gun".
         "The only thing I have to say about it is that the title tune started
         off as a cover of 'Hot Water' by Level 42 (oh yeah add them to my
         favourite music list). It went badly awry by the end of the 1st 10
         seconds though and I decided to change it to something else!" (MG)
(#6)
  TITLE: Tea for Two [from the musical No, No, Nanette]
 ARTIST: Irving Caesar (lyrics), Vincent Youmans (music)
COMMENT: First appeared in the 1924 musical 'No, No, Nanette', later featured
         in the 1950 movie 'Tea for Two'.

 ARTIST: Yellow Magic Orchestra (YMO)

  TITLE: <?>
 ARTIST: Alfred Newman
COMMENT: This version has been used by 20th Century Fox since 1954.

/Galway_Martin/Green_Beret.sid
COMMENT: Covers tunes from the arcade game of "Green Beret" except for tune #1
         and possibly tune #10.
         "Most of the arcade games we worked on has simpler sound chips than
         the C64's, so I was able to 'beef up the music'". (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Night in Shanghai [from Concerts in China]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre
COMMENT: Starting from 0:54 it is perhaps inspired by it. According to Galway,
         he is the least happy with this music amongst all of his tunes.
(#4)
  TITLE: The Star Spangled Banner (National Anthem of the U.S.A.)
 ARTIST: Sir Francis Scott Key (lyrics), John Stafford Smith (music)
(#6)
  TITLE: La Marseillaise (French National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle

/Galway_Martin/Helikopter_Jagd.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Ivory Tower [from the movie The Never Ending Story]
 ARTIST: Giorgio Moroder
COMMENT: "I was still freelancing when I worked on that music first in 1984,
         and I just said to Tony Pomfret 'what do you want for the music?' to
         which he replied 'I want the B-side from the Limahl single
         "Neverending Story" I bought the other day.' At no time were we
         thinking Ocean would publish a "Neverending Story" game, it was very
         much just a cool tune to do. (It was a Georgio Moroder filler tune,
         whose style I had a lot of respect for as a producer). It was the
         first tune I did pulse-width sweeps on, but didn't get released 'til
         after a bunch of other games had come out I think. The sound blew
         everyone away." (MG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Ocean Loader 2
 ARTIST: Martin Galway
COMMENT: This short jingle is an extract of Ocean Loader 2 at about 0:17-0:26.

/Galway_Martin/Highlander.sid
  TITLE: A Kind of Magic [from the movie Highlander]
 ARTIST: Queen
COMMENT: According to Galway, it took him two days to do this tune.

/Galway_Martin/Hunchback_II.sid
COMMENT: "Bill [Barna] & Tony [Pomfret] convinced me to stay up overnight with
         them finishing 'Hunchback 2' on a cold night in November 1984 so they
         could get their bonuses! (I didn't get a cut of those bonuses
         though... HEY!) I had never been up overnight before and it was a new
         experience, especially since I had to get to college the following
         day..." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Hyper_Sports.sid
COMMENT: Tunes #1 to #24 and #26 are covers of the arcade version.
(#25)
COMMENT: Same as /Galway_Martin/Rolands_Ratrace.sid, Tune #3.
(#26)
  TITLE: Titles [from the movie Chariots of Fire]
 ARTIST: Vangelis

/Galway_Martin/Insects_in_Space.sid
COMMENT: "I am sorry to see that most composers these days don't have access to
         the kind of tricks I was able to do (being a programmer), which for
         example allowed me to create the 'buzzing bees' effect at the
         beginning of the tune. Too bad, eh?"
         "Well by the time I got to that game (1988) I was a bit hard up for
         ideas. I didn't know what to do with so few notes available! I wanted
         my tunes to build up into much larger entities but I always hit this
         limit. Plus the time at which that game was developed was a pretty
         rough time for Sensi, none of us were too happy at the time. Insects
         In Space was a victim of this. True though, it certainly has
         'character', but it just doesn't go on LONG enough, don't you agree?"
         (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Match_Day.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Offside [from the TV programme Match Of The Day]
 ARTIST: Stoller
COMMENT: The title music from the British BBC TV football programme, "Match of
         the Day".

/Galway_Martin/Miami_Vice.sid
COMMENT: "The Miami Vice game was a very quick job. I had been handed 'Miami
         Vice' and 'Highlander' because the outside development team working on
         it hadn't worked out who was going to do the sound (notice those games
         have little or no sound-effects), so I did my best in a very short
         time. I [...] picked 'The Chase' and the 'Main Theme' as the two tunes
         I would do. We had settled on two modes for the game - in your car and
         out of it I think. (Or maybe it was in the game and out of it, I can't
         remember.) I started on 'The Chase' and if you listen to the first few
         seconds of that you can hear the basis of that super-filter-echo tune
         that is so cool. I recall David Collier was sitting in the office with
         me while I was working on it. But while messing with it while everyone
         else was at lunch, I came across this cool sound. I added to it and
         added to it, and when we applied the non-sync'd filter sweep we both
         flipped out! I decided to abandon the conversion of that tune and
         simply go with the cool sounds I had stumbled upon. When the guys came
         back from lunch and listened to it they swore that there was a
         cassette deck connected somewhere and it wasn't the C64 playing it!
         Such a sound had not been heard before by any of us out of the C64. So
         I extended it and turned it into this tripping-out 11-minute piece.
         The main theme itself... I simply did my best with no drums (Rob
         Hubbard's strength). I think my strength with guitar solos helped pull
         it off. Both of those problematic games benefited from my music,
         actually, and the Ocean management were very relieved
         (understatement)." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Evan (Instrumental) [from the TV series Miami Vice]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer
COMMENT: Martin did an over-extended remix.
(#2)
  TITLE: Miami Vice Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

/Galway_Martin/Microprose_Soccer_indoor.sid
COMMENT: These are the tunes from the indoor game of Microprose Soccer. Also,
         see comment for /Galway_Martin/Microprose_Soccer_outdoor.sid.
(#5)
  TITLE: Wilhelm Tell Overture
 ARTIST: Gioacchino Antonio Rossini
(#13)
  TITLE: Orpheus in the Underworld Overture
 ARTIST: Jacques Offenbach
(#14)
  TITLE: When the Saints Go Marching In
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: American folk song. Sung by British football fans at matches.
(#15)
  TITLE: Battle Hymn of the Republic
 ARTIST: Julia Ward Howe
(#17)
  TITLE: An der schönen blauen Donau (Blue Danube)
 ARTIST: Johann Strauß

/Galway_Martin/Microprose_Soccer_outdoor.sid
COMMENT: "Well, a tune could only be hard to compose if I was hard-up for ideas
         at the time - if it was a conversion/arrangement of someone else's
         music it wouldn't be composition, right? 'Microprose Soccer' and
         'Insects In Space' were the toughest, by that definition." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Mikie.sid
COMMENT: All tunes are covers of the arcade version (except maybe tune #1?).
(#6)
  TITLE: A Hard Day's Night [from the movie]
 ARTIST: The Beatles
(#9)
  TITLE: Twist And Shout
 ARTIST: Phil Medley & Bert Russell

/Galway_Martin/Never_Ending_Story.sid
  TITLE: Never Ending Story [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Giorgio Moroder, performed by Limahl

/Galway_Martin/Ocean_Loader_1.sid
COMMENT: "The 'version 1' is a real tune, it was really like that on
         Hypersports and maybe one or two other games before Comic Bakery
         (Cyclone would have used it, for example, but it was never released by
         Ocean). The delay at 02:03.00 really is supposed to be a delay of 4
         beats." (MG)
         Because of the delay Martin mentioned at 2:03, it led a lot of people
         to believe later parts of the tune went out of synch and it was
         bugged. However, this has been confirmed as intentional. This version
         was known to have been used in Hyper Sports and Transformers.

/Galway_Martin/Ocean_Loader_2.sid
COMMENT: "'version 2' was a reworking of that tune that I did in late 1985 for
         Comic Bakery. There was actually supposed to be separate loading music
         for every game - that was my plan.  However, I was running out of time
         on projects and in the case of C.B. I simply reworked an older piece.
         After that I _really_ didn't have time to mess with it, and it stuck
         in universal use. Rambo was the only one that got its own loading
         music as part of this plan." (MG)
         This version was in use for many Ocean/Imagine games from late 1985 to
         mid 1987.

/Galway_Martin/Parallax.sid
COMMENT: Before starting on this game Galway bought Rendez-vous (by Jean Michel
         Jarre). He listened to it daily. His CD player broke 2 weeks later and
         didn't get repaired for 2 months, during which time Martin worked on
         Parallax, without realizing that Rendez-vous was unconsciously
         creeping into the music. He realized it only after he played the album
         again after the game was already shipped.
         "[Parallax] was 11 minutes long, certainly my longest at the time. I
         took my development gear home to work on it for a week or two. I just
         said to myself 'OK, it's going to be this mega-tune, so the intro has
         to be mega'. The intro took up two-thirds of the tune! I actually got
         bored with it, and stuck that silly melody on the end which doesn't
         really match. Going back I would have made it less melodic. I wanted
         to reflect the gigantic visual proportions represented by the parallax
         effect in the game so that's why it has an 'epic' feel."(MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Rendez-vous [from Rendez-vous]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/Galway_Martin/Ping_Pong.sid
COMMENT: "Can't quite remember what happened with 'Ping Pong'. I seem to
         remember not having very much time to work on it. I do recall working
         late on it after everyone else had left, because perhaps I was going
         on holiday the next day or something. (Was it around September-1987?)
         The arcade game didn't have any music on the 'press start' screen, so
         it would have been a natural for an original tune. Maybe everyone
         regarded it as a 'baby game' which didn't merit much attention. CAN'T
         QUITE REMEMBER, sorry!" (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Rambo_First_Blood_Part_II.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: The Morse-code heard in voice 1 at the start of the tune spells out
         the names of the games' creators. The decoded Morse-code is below.
         The (*) denotes where the tone of the Morse-code drops. The spelling
         is slightly incorrect, letter 'i' always translates as an 'e'.
         "I wrote that morse code program myself. Nobody touched it but me. It
         was written to handle any text. And I spelt the text right! So - if
         you're right - the problem must have been the software. I'm assuming
         my morsecode book was right of course ;)" (MG)
         -...|.|.-..|.-..|-...|.-|.-.|-.|.-|
         B    E  L    L    B    A  R  N  A              (Bill Barna)
         -..|.-|...-|.|-..|-.-.|---|.-..|.-..|.|.|.-.|
         D   A  V    E D   C    O   L    L    E E R     (David Collier)
         --|.-|.-.|-|.|-.|--.|(*).-|.-..|.--|.-|-.--|
         M  A  R   T E N  G      A  L    W   A  Y       (Martin Galway)
         -|---|-.|-.--|.--.|---|--|..-.|.-.|.|-|
         T O   N  Y    P    O   M  F    R   E T         (Tony Pomfret)
         ..(*).|-|.|...-|.|.--|.-|....|.|-..
         S      T E V    E W   A  H    E D              (Steve Wahid)
(#2)
  TITLE: Stories [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II] (2:56-3:06)
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
(#3)
COMMENT: This is used throughout the moviescore in different places.
         Some parts start with it, some have it in the middle. It's a vital
         ingredient in the whole score.
(#5)
  TITLE: Stories [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II]
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
(#6)
  TITLE: Stories [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II]
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith

  TITLE: Preparation
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
(#9)
  TITLE: Stories [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II]
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith

  TITLE: Main Title [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II]
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
COMMENT: This is covered from First Patrol (Brian Carter)'s disco-version.
(#20)
  TITLE: Escape From Torture [from the movie Rambo First Blood Part II]
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
COMMENT: It's a part of the lead from this piece, only Galway plays it 4 times
         faster.
(#21)
  TITLE: Ride of the Valkyries
 ARTIST: Richard Wagner

/Galway_Martin/Rastan.sid
COMMENT: Covers arcade version.
         "The most difficult adaption of a piece of music from a game was the
         Rastan Saga music, that took a while to get all fitted into three
         channels."
         "[...] it was really hard to fit all that stuff on the C64,
         particularly since the dynamic range of arcade game music was starting
         to rise at last, something which the C64 doesn't have much of. (I
         always had that problem with movie conversions of course.)"(MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)
(#2)
  TITLE: Agressive World [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)
(#3)
  TITLE: Re-In-Carnation [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)
(#4)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)
(#5)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)
(#6)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Rastan Saga]
 ARTIST: Masahiko Takaki (Zuntata)

/Galway_Martin/Rolands_Ratrace.sid
COMMENT: "Once I had finished on 'Roland's Rat Race', which took a month,
         [Ocean] agreed to suspend my tasks as a programmer and my employment
         as game sound guy began." (MG)
         "[...] the sounds are a bit poor. I didn't develop pulse-width
         modulation until the next project, which at the time was called
         'Cyclone'. It later came out as 'Helicopter Jagd'. On 'Roland's Rat
         Race' I guess you could say I was still mastering the C64. It was
         January/February 1985, my first project on staff at Ocean (I had done
         quite a few before that as a freelancer but they weren't comfortable
         employing someone SOLELY TO DO MUSIC... those were the days!)." (MG)
(#3)
COMMENT: Same as /Galway_Martin/Hyper_Sports.sid, Tune #25.

/Galway_Martin/Short_Circuit.sid
COMMENT: "I believe it to be my most elaborate, complete and successful
         conversion of a 'digital audio sourced' tune. ZZAP! 64 only gave the
         music 79%, my worst score since 'Roland's Rat Race', so you can
         imagine my disappointment. One of the other tunes was easy, that's the
         simple ballad melody 'come and follow me', which I was able to arrange
         quite successfully. The other one was a nightmare since it's the tune
         right from the beginning of the movie with all the robotic short notes
         & arpeggios. The tune just built up so massive that the poor C64 was
         short of notes by about 30 seconds into it, so I had to fudge the end
         a bit and make it repeat, basically." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Who's Johnny? [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: El DeBarge
COMMENT: "I also had to do 'Who's Johnny?' by El DeBarge for the 'Short
         Circuit' game, that took 4 weeks to program in with all those slides
         and copies of what the record does, I regarded that as quite an
         achievement since it was kind of a neat tune." (MG)
(#4)
  TITLE: <?> [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: David Shire
COMMENT: This music is played when Johnny 5 comes alive!
(#5)
  TITLE: Come and Follow Me [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: David Shire, Will Jennings & Max Carl
COMMENT: This is the song played under the credits at the end of the movie. It
         is also the theme song of "Number Five".

/Galway_Martin/Slap_Fight.sid
COMMENT: Covers arcade version except for tune #1.
         "I didn't have much memory space, I believe around 5 or 6K, so I was
         delighted to copy the arcade game exactly, which had very simple
         sound! That was my most accurate conversion." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Swag.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: If I Were a Rich Man [from the musical "Fiddler on the Roof"]
 ARTIST: Jerry Bock (music), Sheldon Harnick (lyrics)

/Galway_Martin/Terra_Cresta.sid
COMMENT: "I tried to create this feeling of a massive behemoth robot monster on
         its way to destroy you. Thus the marching beat and the minor chords
         and stark tones. I had to stick in the inevitable jamming solo towards
         the end of course. I was starting to face the glass ceiling imposed by
         the filter on the C64. While my particular SID sounded great, others
         were not like it at all and the solos were almost inaudible! At the
         other extreme the new C64C's were coming out and this filter
         unreliability had been fixed as part of a silicon revision. BUT the
         filters were way too open all the time and you could hardly hear any
         filtering! This caused the filtered note to come out a lot louder than
         it should have and 'stick out' rather unattractively. So I developed a
         'filter adjustment' parameter for my music program which would allow
         the customer to control this filter unreliability and get their
         particular machine to sound cool. But David Collier never put it in
         the options screen. (DOH!) There's always something wrong, eh?" (MG)
(#8)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game]
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida

/Galway_Martin/Times_of_Lore.sid
COMMENT: "I remember I squeezed the code & data for 25 sound-effects into 923
         bytes - not bad, eh?" (MG)
(#1)
COMMENT: "The most complex original tune I did was the 'Times Of Lore' title
         tune, it took 20 days just to do the guitar solos! It has a random
         number generator which selects different guitar solos, but I didn't
         realise that people wouldn't leave it looping for its 11-minute
         duration so the work all got sort of wasted." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Wizball.sid
(#2)
COMMENT: The opening bars of this tune are sampled by the group Console on
         their song "14 Zero Zero".
(#4)
COMMENT: "I was working at the Sensible Software office at the time of the
         major music creation, but the title screen music never got finished.
         When I returned to Ocean I got on with some other things, all the time
         worrying about this unfinished tune. Finally I slapped something on
         the end of it. I knew I could never top the first part, that's what
         the problem was. In my mind the second part of the tune is pretty lame
         compared with the first part. But for some people it represents the
         mysterious, magical, unconventional aspect of 'Wizball' so it fits in
         some ways. But you can tell it's not really like the other music in
         the game, which was primarily developed when I was with the Sensi
         boys, basking in that Sensi VIBE." (MG)
         "I really worked on the sound design of the voices a lot. The music
         seems to "flow" and "breathe" unlike anything before it." (MG)
(#5)
COMMENT: "Tune 5, the bonus screen tune, consists of several short riffs, and
         John Hare came up with the most musical ones on his bass guitar. I
         remember he would come up with the riffs, playing them over and over
         at full volume on his band's P.A. in their rented terraced house in
         Southend (not caring about what the neighbours thought!!!) - and while
         they went out to get me a "blow-out" burger at 3am, I would be
         transcribing it and enhancing it (a little)." (MG)
(#7)
COMMENT: "I composed the high-score music at Ocean after returning from
         Southend. Played it on the synth keyboard there. It's one of the few
         compositions of mine that I can actually play a decent rendition of on
         the piano." (MG)
(#8)
COMMENT: "Chris Yates wrote the game over riff on his electric guitar. They
         were pretty impressed by the translation when they came back with my
         blow-out." (MG)

/Galway_Martin/Yie_Ar_Kung_Fu.sid
COMMENT: All except tune #19 are covers of the arcade version.
(#19)
  TITLE: Magnetic Fields, Part 4 [from Magnetic Fields]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/Galway_Martin/Yie_Ar_Kung_Fu_II.sid
COMMENT: "I just tried to come up with a crazy way of settling on a beginning
         note (my favourite beginning note of course, G - almost everything I
         do is in G). So I plugged in this echoing waveform thing and let it
         rip. The tune isn't particularly Chinese sounding, but I was working
         on producing that 'perfect melody', the one you'd be humming all day,
         you know. That was a phase I went through. [...] The sound I was
         converting from was itself a conversion of the arcade cabinet, which I
         have NEVER SEEN. It sounded like it was a lame conversion too, so I
         easily did a better sounding version. (The MSX's music only used two
         notes at once, for example.)" (MG)
(#5)
  TITLE: Firecracker [from Yellow Magic Orchestra]
 ARTIST: Yellow Magic Orchestra (YMO)

/GAMES/A-F/Donkey_Kong_1986.sid
COMMENT: All the music for this game was composed using Electrosound, a popular
         music utility. Martin Galway has confirmed to us that he never
         composed with Electrosound, and so this means also he did NOT compose
         this music. The music is from the arcade game.

/GAMES/S-Z/Summer_Games.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Bugler's Dream
 ARTIST: Leo Arnaud
COMMENT: Introduced during the 1968 Olympic Games, Grenoble.
(#2)
  TITLE: The Star Spangled Banner (National Anthem of the U.S.A.)
 ARTIST: Sir Francis Scott Key (lyrics), John Stafford Smith (music)
(#3)
  TITLE: La Marseillaise (French National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle
(#4)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.
(#5)
  TITLE: Deutschlandlied (German National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Franz Joseph Haydn (music), A. H. Hoffmann von Fallersleben (lyrics)
(#6)
  TITLE: Land der Berge, Land am Strome (Austrian National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Paula von Preradovic (lyrics), Johann Holtzer (music)
(#7)
  TITLE: Fratelli D'Italia (Italian National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Goffredo Mameli (lyrics), Michele Novaro (music)
(#8)
COMMENT: Epyx's theme song?
(#9)
  TITLE: Rondeau
 ARTIST: Jean Joseph Mouret
(#10)
  TITLE: Internatsional - Anthem of the Communist Parties of the World
 ARTIST: Pierre Degeyter (music), Eugene Pottier (lyrics)
(#11)
  TITLE: O Canada (Canadian National Anthem)
 ARTIST: J. A. Routhier (French), J. R. S. Wier (English), C. Lavallée (music)
(#12)
  TITLE: Himno Nacional Mexicano (Mexican National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Francisco González Bocanegra (lyrics), Jaime Nunó (music)
(#13)
  TITLE: La Marcha Real (Spanish National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Unknown
COMMENT: The origins of this song are unknown, documents date back to 1761
         where the song appears as "La Marcha Granadera" (March of the
         Grenadiers), already then with the mention "unknown author".
(#14)
  TITLE: Kong Kristian stod ved højen mast (Danish National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Music from around 1770, lyrics by Johannes Ewald (1779)
(#15)
  TITLE: Waltzing Matilda
 ARTIST: Marie Cowan (music), A.B. Paterson (lyrics)
COMMENT: Used as the music for Australia.
(#16)
  TITLE: Amhrán na bhFiann (Irish National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Peadar Kearney & Patrick Heaney (music), Peadar Kearney (lyrics)
(#17)
  TITLE: Hino Nacional Do Brasil (Brazilian National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Francisco Manoel da Silva (music), J. Osório Duque Estrada (lyrics)
(#18)
  TITLE: Kimigayo (Japanese National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Hiromori Hayashi (music), lyrics come from an ancient poem
(#19)
  TITLE: Wilhelmus van Nassouwe (Dutch National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Marnix van St. Aldegonde (lyrics), Valerius (music)
COMMENT: It is based on an old French soldiers tune.
(#20)
  TITLE: Jumpman Junior Theme
 ARTIST: Randy Glover <?>
(#21)
  TITLE: Ja, Vi Elsker Dette Landet (Norwegian National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson (lyrics), Rikard Nordraak (music)

### GAMES\ ###################################################################

### HOLGER GEHRMANN ##########################################################

/Gehrmann_Holger/
COMMENT: Holger Gehrmann's own comments are indicated by (HG). All
         tunes are confirmed by Holger Gehrmann to be his.

/Gehrmann_Holger/Action_on_Protection.sid
COMMENT: "My first game with scrolling. The songs are conversions of classic
         themes from 'Johann Sebastian Bach'." (HG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Badinerie [from Orchestral Suite No.2]
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach

/Gehrmann_Holger/Galactic_Meteors.sid
COMMENT: "One of the first machine language based songs I made on the C-64.
         'Soundcontrol' didn't have any fancy features at this time, so the
         songs aren't the greatest. Btw, I thought this game had never been
         released (since I never got any royalties)." (HG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Making Your Mind Up
 ARTIST: Bucks Fizz

/Gehrmann_Holger/Graffiti_Man.sid
COMMENT: "I didn't like the game, so this song for Rainbow Arts isn't my best
         one..." (HG)

/Gehrmann_Holger/Hollywood_Poker.sid
COMMENT: "I think this was the first song with the enhanced version of
         'Soundcontrol'. Now it was a sound programming language (SOPROL) where
         you could type in your songs like a basic program (with labels, sound
         commands and so on), and a compiler converted it to machine language.
         Unfortunately the compiled songs were running VERY slow because of the
         structure of the SOPROL language." (HG)

/Gehrmann_Holger/Input_64_Issue_03_85.sid
COMMENT: "For about 6 months I worked at Heise Verlag, and they had a radio
         commercial and wanted it to be converted to the C-64.
         I didn't have an assembler at that time, so I did it with a machine
         language monitor (same as with Galactic Meteors and AOP)." (HG)

/Gehrmann_Holger/North-Sea_Inferno.sid
COMMENT: "Magic Bytes asked me if I could help them with the game because the
         programmers left the company and went back to Denmark. I finished the
         Atari ST and Amiga version and did the C64 soundtrack. Btw, the
         programmers from Denmark released the game too, it was called 'Persian
         Gulf Inferno'. Magic Bytes sued them for doing this." (HG)
         "In the game credits there might be an 'alias name' (since I wasn't
         allowed to work for other companies at that time :-)" (HG)

/Gehrmann_Holger/Oil_Imperium.sid
COMMENT: "Karsten Obarski did some great songs for Oil Imperium Amiga, and it
         was my job to convert them to the C64 and IBM PC. My favorite is song
         #3 (Action Sequence 1 'oilfield burning')." (HG)
(#2)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Title Tune [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#3)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Oilfield Burning [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#4)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Drilling Sequence [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#5)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Pipeline Building [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski

/Gehrmann_Holger/Operation_Hongkong.sid
COMMENT: See /Gehrmann_Holger/Top_Secret.sid.

/Gehrmann_Holger/Top_Secret.sid
COMMENT: "[This and Operation Hongkong are] two adventure games I made. They
         were coded in a special 'adventure programming language' so I was able
         to convert them for the Atari ST within 2 days (without sound though).
         The Operation Hongkong song was done with a newer version of
         Soundcontrol." (HG)

### FRED GRAY ################################################################

/Gray_Fred/
COMMENT: All Fred's comments are denoted by (FG).

/Gray_Fred/Ah_Diddums.sid
COMMENT: From (0:41-0:45) it covers a famous children's "song".

/Gray_Fred/Army_Moves.sid
(#2)
  TITLE: Colonel Bogey (0:00-0:42)
 ARTIST: Kenneth J. Alford
  TITLE: The Stars and Stripes Forever (1:08-1:38)
 ARTIST: John Philip Sousa

/Gray_Fred/Batman_The_Caped_Crusader.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: Original music with hints of the famous "Batman" TV series theme.
(#3)
  TITLE: Batman TV series theme
 ARTIST: Neal Hefti
COMMENT: "SFX told to write music to suit the movie, but they didn't have any
         footage to show me - big joke hahaha." (FG)

/Gray_Fred/Dantes_Inferno.sid
COMMENT: "Dante's Inferno was a challenge. I only had 3K of memory and no
         interrupt time to use. I listened to Chopin's 'Dante' music but it was
         awful chromatic crap, so I used Bach, and played some tunes forward
         and again backwards to save memory." (FG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Antioch (Joy to the World)
 ARTIST: Isaac Watts (lyrics), Lowell Mason (music)
COMMENT: Mason borrowed two phrases from Händel's Messiah, "Lift Up Your
         Heads," and "Comfort Ye", when writing this melody.
(#4)
  TITLE: Toccata [from Toccata and Fugue in D Minor (BWV 565)]
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
(#5)
  TITLE: <?>
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
(#7)
  TITLE: <?>
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
COMMENT: Same as #5!

/Gray_Fred/Enigma_Force.sid
COMMENT: "I blindly played some chords on the keyboard, and thought 'that
         sounds kewl'". (FG)

/Gray_Fred/Fox_Fights_Back.sid
COMMENT: "Someone described it as pop goes the classics!" (FG)
(#1)
COMMENT: The sound effects are supposed to be the nagging wife. I've had lots
         of experience of that hehe...I love her really. :o) " (FG)
(#3)
  TITLE: March of the Toreadors [from Carmen] (0:00-0:40)
 ARTIST: Georges Bizet
  TITLE: Symphony No. 40, First Movement (0:56-1:11)
 ARTIST: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
  TITLE: Hungarian Dances No. 5 (1:27-1:53)
 ARTIST: Johannes Brahms

         recorded for their 1985 FA Cup Final appearance), hence the can can."
         (FG)
  TITLE: The Stars and Stripes Forever (0:00)

COMMENT: Often known to sports fans as "Here We Go".

 ARTIST: Traditional Negro Spiritual

COMMENT: American folk song. Sung by British football fans at matches.
  TITLE: The Stars and Stripes Forever (1:34)

COMMENT: Often known to sports fans as "Here We Go".

/Gray_Fred/Transformers.sid
  TITLE: Transformers Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Ford Kinder & Anne Bryant
COMMENT: "Transformers was a nightmare. I couldn't get it right and was going
         to refuse to do it. They still used it. Yuk..." (FG)

/Gray_Fred/West_Bank.sid
(#2)
  TITLE: Something Doing
 ARTIST: Scott Joplin
COMMENT: "I knew it was Scott Joplin, as soon as I heard it. I checked the key,
         so I went to the library, borrowed a book of Joplin stuff, looked at
         all the tunes in F major, and I found it. Ventura - music
         detective!!!" (FG)
(#4)
  TITLE: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Ennio Morricone
COMMENT: "I couldn't resist putting this in, hehe - I once put 'Stand by your
         man' in a similar western type game on the ST." (FG)
(#5)
  TITLE: High Noon (Do Not Forsake Me Oh My Darling) [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Dimitri Tiomkin (music), Ned Washington (lyrics)

  TITLE: Miami Vice Theme [from the TV series] (4:04-4:50)
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

COMMENT: This tunes were actually first used in the Digital Excess demo Space
         Bubbles. Although finished in 1990 the game wasn't released until
         1992, the doc file was done some while after the game itself was
         finished.

/Hartwig_Stefan/Iceblaster.sid

/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio.sid
(#3)

         "Iceblaster", (c) 1994 Dome Developments.
(#4)
  TITLE: Living on Video [from Living on Video] (0:11)
 ARTIST: Trans-X
(#6)
COMMENT: Later used as Side Border Music, (c) 1990 Digital Excess.
         This tune later was also used as loader tune for the System 3 game
         Vendetta, that - just like Myth and Turrican - was timex protected and
         mastered by Markus Wiederstein. In need for a loader tune Wiederstein
         chose tunes the composer gave to Digital Marketing. That's why
         Hartwig's tunes ended up in the games.
(#7)
COMMENT: Later used as the loading theme to the disk version of "Myth", (c)
         1989 System 3.

(#1)
COMMENT: Later used as the disk loading theme to "Turrican", (c) 1990 Rainbow
         Arts.
(#6)
COMMENT: Later used as the intro theme to the disk version of "Turrican 2 - The
         Final Fight", (c) 1991 Rainbow Arts.

### ROB HUBBARD ##############################################################

/Hubbard_Rob/
COMMENT: All of these tunes have been confirmed by Hubbard to be his. People
         have often stolen Hubbard's routine causing some tunes to be falsely
         credited to him.
         Hubbard's own comments are denoted by (RH).

/Hubbard_Rob/ACE_II.sid
COMMENT: "This was supposed to be the usual Top Gun type Danger Zone music. It
         turned out much better than I expected as certain musical styles can
         be difficult to do on the C64." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Action_Biker.sid
COMMENT: "Action B was a very early game and very conservative in its approach
         - it was my idea of giving them what I thought they wanted, a simple
         cute tune....." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Auf_Wiedersehen_Monty.sid
COMMENT: Tune #1 is a joint venture between Rob Hubbard and Ben Daglish. The
         other sub-tunes were done by Rob Hubbard.
         "I just think that Gremlin thought that the original Monty On The Run
         was very popular and they just didn't want to totally move away from
         what I did on the original, so they asked me to spend 2 days working
         with Ben at their office and that's what happened." (RH)
(#2)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.
(#3)
  TITLE: La Marseillaise (French National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle
(#4)
  TITLE: Deutschlandlied (German National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Franz Joseph Haydn (music), A. H. Hoffmann von Fallersleben (lyrics)
(#5)
  TITLE: O Tannenbaum
 ARTIST: Traditional, A. Zarnack & Ernst Anschütz (lyrics)
COMMENT: German folk song.
(#6)
  TITLE: Symphony No. 40, First Movement
 ARTIST: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
(#9)
  TITLE: Zorba, the Greek
 ARTIST: Mikis Theodorakis
(#10)
  TITLE: 'O sole mio
 ARTIST: Eduardo di Capua (music), Giovanni Capurro (lyrics)
(#11)
  TITLE: Viva España
 ARTIST: Leo Caerts (music), Leo Rozenstraten & Leif Nilsson (lyrics)
(#12)
  TITLE: Tulpen uit Amsterdam
 ARTIST: Herman Emmink
(#13)
  TITLE: Swedish Chef Theme [from the TV series Muppet Show]
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Quite likely inspired by the Swedish Chef Theme, although Rob Hubbard
         doesn't remember ever having heard the original.

/Hubbard_Rob/Bangkok_Knights.sid
  TITLE: Eye of the Tiger [from the movie Rocky III] (5:43-6:00)
 ARTIST: Survivor

/Hubbard_Rob/BMX_Kidz_PSID.sid
COMMENT: The sampled voice saying "Go!" is actually Hubbard himself!
(#1)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#2)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#3)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard

 ARTIST: Yip
COMMENT: Yip did this hi-score music, which is the 'reprise' version of "5th
         Dream About Happiness" found in /Yip/Scroll_Machine.sid #1.

/Hubbard_Rob/Chain_Reaction.sid
  TITLE: Zoolook (remix) [from Zoolook]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/Hubbard_Rob/Chicken_Song.sid
COMMENT: "The Chicken Song" was from the British TV show "Spitting Image", and
         featured ridiculous lyrics such as "Hold a chicken in the air, stick a
         deckchair up your nose". (Please note that STIL does NOT recommend you
         do this!). The song was credited to Spitting Image.
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (0:00)
 ARTIST: Philip Pope
  TITLE: Anyone Can Fall In Love [from TV series Eastenders] (1:24)
 ARTIST: Simon May, performed by Anita Dobson
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (1:55)
 ARTIST: Philip Pope
  TITLE: The Power of Love (2:39)
 ARTIST: Jennifer Rush
COMMENT: The notes are out of tune.
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (3:17)
 ARTIST: Philip Pope
  TITLE: Monty on the Run, Tune #1 (4:28)
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/Hubbard_Rob/Commando.sid
COMMENT: "There is an interesting story behind Commando. I went down to their
         office and started working on it late at night, and worked on it
         through the night. I took one listen to the original arcade version
         and started working on the c64 version. I think they wanted some
         resemblance to the arcade version, but I just did what I wanted to do.
         By the time everyone arrived at 8.00am in the morning, I had loaded
         the main tune on every C64 in the building! I got my cheque and was on
         a train home by 10.00 am..." (RH)
(#1)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Commando]
 ARTIST: Tamayo Kawamoto
(#3)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Commando]
 ARTIST: Tamayo Kawamoto

/Hubbard_Rob/Confuzion.sid
  TITLE: Confuzion
 ARTIST: Private Property
COMMENT: Included as "Confuzion - The Music" on the B-side of the game tape.

/Hubbard_Rob/Cracker_Mix.sid
COMMENT: Slower version of /Hubbard_Rob/Human_Race.sid, Tune #5.

/Hubbard_Rob/Deep_Strike.sid
  TITLE: March [from the movie "1941"]
 ARTIST: John Williams

/Hubbard_Rob/Delta.sid
COMMENT: "[...] The Delta music loader and ingame music was Gary Liddon's idea.
         [...] He was the producer at Thalamus at the time. He told Rob Hubbard
         to make the ingame music like the 2nd track from Dark Side of the Moon
         by Pink Floyd." (Info from Matt Furniss.)
         "The small jingles are all small clips from Sanxion and Romeo/Juliet
         music. They were all supposed to be for short stingers such as end of
         level, extra life etc..."
         "Delta was based on this minimalist composition technique inspired by
         Glass and a bit of Pink Floyd. It was quite hard to do and required
         some custom code to the driver to do it. The music was tedious to
         debug. The other Delta stuff was more conventional - I quite liked the
         other tunes. Delta was spread over a 2 week period....." (RH)
         According to Hubbard, Kentilla and Delta were the most complicated one
         to compose, they took the longest time to do and they both drove him
         insane.
(#1)
  TITLE: On the Run [from the Dark Side of the Moon] (0:00)
 ARTIST: Pink Floyd
COMMENT: Inspired by the above tune.
  TITLE: Pruit Igoe [from the movie Koyaanisqatsi] (4:00)
 ARTIST: Philip Glass
COMMENT: Inspired by the above tune.
  TITLE: Resource [from the movie Koyaanisqatsi] (5:26-9:07)
 ARTIST: Philip Glass
COMMENT: Inspired by the above tune.
(#3)
  TITLE: Thalamusik [from Sanxion]
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: Covered from Hubbard's own Sanxion, Tune #1.
(#4)
  TITLE: Thalamusik [from Sanxion]
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: Covered from Hubbard's own Sanxion, Tune #1.

  TITLE: Thalamusik [from Sanxion]
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

COMMENT: Covered from Hubbard's own Sanxion, Tune #1.

  TITLE: The Montagues and Capulets [from Romeo and Juliet]

/Hubbard_Rob/Delta_Mix-E_Load_loader.sid
COMMENT: Delta's intro allowed the user to select the instruments for each
         voice while the game loaded. This rip here is basically a mix of many
         of the instrument combinations selectable in the intro.

/Hubbard_Rob/Dragons_Lair_Part_II.sid
COMMENT: The full title of this game is "Dragon's Lair Part II: Escape From
         Singe's Castle". Several of the songs are covers of the original
         "Dragon's Lair" tunes, see /GAMES/A-F/Dragons_Lair.sid.
         "All the tunes for Dragons Lair 2 were written in 1 afternoon, not the
         whole lot but the basis for them. I sat at the keyboard and just
         recorded myself playing for 3 hours !!" (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Final_Synth_Sample_I.sid
